fields.Work: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman with Strictures on Political and Moral Subjects
fields.Description: This is a first edition of Mary Wollstonecraft’s pioneering work of feminist philosophy. Written partly as a reaction to Edmund Burke’s _Reflections on the French Revolution_ (1790), which called for more traditional societal structures, Wollstonecraft advocates for the education for women and for their ability to support themselves.
fields.Author: Mary Wollstonecraft

fields.Description: This work illustrates the poem 'Neijmantototsintle' by Ateri Miyawatl, with linocuts by Francisco Villa, and printed by Elies Plana. The poem was written in Nahuatl in 2016, then translated into Catalan and English. Nahuatl is an indigenous language currently spoken by approximately 1.7 million people, mostly in Central Mexico, and was used by the Aztec and Toltec civilizations.
fields.Author: Ateri Miyawatl, illustrated by Francisco Villa

fields.Description: This first edition of the influential book by Josef Albers, a German-born American artist, presents his color theory principles. The illustrations are studies composed of color-printed paper and mounted colored paper, some with cutouts. This book was donated to Swarthmore by Lucy Carol Davis, Class of 1971.
fields.Author: Josef Albers

fields.Description: The poet W. H. Auden taught at Swarthmore from 1942 through 1945. He used this notebook as a workbook, in which he wrote drafts of poems and essays. It covers the period from September, 1932 to the end of 1934. Early drafts of many of his writings of that period are in it—poems published in 'Look, Stranger,' Auden's second volume of poems, published in 1936; a long speech from 'The Group Movement and the Middle Classes;’ and 'Art and Psychology.’ The workbook is accompanied by a letter of presentation dated August 7, 1966. It is inscribed to James F. Govan, Librarian of Swarthmore College Library. Swarthmore also has a typewriter owned by Auden in the collection.
fields.Author: W. H. Auden

fields.Work: Fl. Vegetii Renati Viri ilustris de re Militari libri quatuor
fields.Description: This book containing illustrations depicting Roman military practices and weaponry was used as a military guide into the 19th century. The work is part of the Bathe Collection, comprising some 1,500 volumes on the history of technology before and after the Industrial Revolution. It was amassed by and then willed to Swarthmore by Greville Bathe, an author of several books on the history of technology.
fields.Author: Flavius Vegetius Renatus

fields.Description: Peter Apian, also known as Petrus Apianus, was a German printer and mathematician who later became a royal astronomer. His work is based on the Ptolemaic theory that the Earth is stationary at the center of the universe and all other planets revolve around it in circular orbits. _Astronomicum Caesareum_ was published just before Copernicus proposed a new theory in 1543 of the sun being at the center of the universe. The book contains hand-colored volvelles, moving paper wheels that function as astrolabes to determine the placement of the planets. Swarthmore's copy was given by Elizabeth Wilcox Schickele, whose son Peter graduated from Swarthmore in 1957. She gave the book, “In memory of Margaret Ionides Cochran, fine astronomer and friend. With warm thanks to Hewitt Cochran.”
fields.Author: Peter Apian

fields.Work: [Pages 15-16] of The Works of Geoffrey Chaucer, now newly imprinted
fields.Description: This leaf is from the most famous of the books printed by Kelmscott Press, _The Works of Geoffrey Chaucer, now newly imprinted. _The press was founded by artist and designer William Morris, associated with the British Arts and Crafts Movement. Swarthmore acquired the leaf in 1948 from Elizabeth Griscom Marot (1863–1950). She was a bookbinder from a Philadelphia Quaker family who studied and worked with T. J. Cobden-Sanderson of the Doves Press in England, one of the best known of the Arts & Crafts presses. Marot was a member of Swarthmore Monthly Meeting and lived locally.
fields.Author: Geoffrey Chaucer, printed by Kelmscott Press

fields.Work: The Poetical Works of Oliver Goldsmith
fields.Description: This book is noteworthy for its double fore-edge painting of the Oxford and Cambridge skylines on the book page edges. The painting by Bolton Corney is invisible when the book is closed but seen when the pages are fanned; Cambridge when fanned in one direction, Oxford in the other. The technique became popular in the 18th century. The book was donated by Mary Palmer Lichtenberg, Class of 1931.
fields.Author: Oliver Goldsmith, painting by Bolton Corney

fields.Work: The Herball or Generall Historie of Plantes
fields.Description: This work by the English botanist John Gerard was the standard reference work on botany in the 17th century. Containing woodcut illustrations, it remained influential until the 18th century. Swarthmore's copy was donated by Richard & Alice Walking, Classes of 1949 & 1950.
fields.Author: John Gerard

fields.Work: In Their Memory: Human Rights Violations Chile (1973-1990)
fields.Description: _In Their Memory_ is a book that carries forward the protest begun by the families of the disappeared in Chile during the military dictatorship (1973-1990). By documenting the identities of the victims, it invites reflection and puts forth a message of hope founded in truth. —Maria Veronica San Martin
fields.Author: Maria Veronica San Martin

fields.Description: In 2017, Kitty Maryatt recreated the iconic _La Prose du Transsibérien_. The original work by Sonia Delaunay-Terk and Blaise Cendrars, published in 1913, is considered one of the most beautiful artists’ books of all time. The work is based on a poem by Cendrars about travel through Russia on the Trans-Siberian Express in 1905, accompanied by pochoir (stencil) prints by Sonia Delaunay-Terk.
fields.Author: Kitty Maryatt, Sonia Delaunay-Terk, Blaise Cendrars

fields.Work: Hierīn sind begriffen vier Bücher von menschlicher Proportion
fields.Description: This is a first edition of Albrecht Dürer's book on human proportions, published after Dürer's death. The book includes woodcuts and diagrams by Dürer in the original parchment binding.
fields.Author: Albrecht Dürer

fields.Description: Philadelphia Quaker Elizabeth Griscom Marot designed the gold-tooled brown morocco binding of this work in 1907. Marot worked as a binder for the prestigious Doves Press, founded by T. J. Cobden-Sanderson. This copy includes two pencil drawing designs by Marot for the binding. She donated this work to Swarthmore in 1948, along with a number of other classic works from the Arts and Crafts Movement.
fields.Author: T. J. Cobden-Sanderson, book design by Elizabeth Griscom Marot

fields.Description: This work contains the only known published poetry by Toni Morrison, accompanied by letterpress silhouettes by renowned artist Kara Walker. It is signed by both Toni Morrison and Kara Walker.
fields.Author: Toni Morrison, illustrated by Kara Walker

fields.Description: _Brooklyn Bridge: A Love Song_ is a book that includes 5 abstract representations of the Brooklyn Bridge painted on sanded aluminum pages. The imagery on the metallic pages is indistinct, yet hints at a powerful substance that lends to the authenticity of the figures—you can feel the presence of the bridge in the aluminum. —Donald Glaister
fields.Author: Donald Glaister

fields.Description: Artnoose began letterpress printing the zine _Ker-bloom!_ in the summer of 1996 when she decided that zines and letterpress could in fact merge … Each issue is its own little story, a brief snippet into Artnoose's life and how it expands to jibe with the ‘bigger picture,’ or in some cases, how it runs completely counter to any overall descriptive narrative. Past themes have included: substitute teaching, home surgery, modern protests, bicycles, torrid love affairs, and tumultuous break-ups. —Artnoose
fields.Author: Artnoose

fields.Work: The Book of Job: According to the Authorized Version of MDCXI, Following the Arrangement of the Temple Bible
fields.Description: This book was printed in the Arts and Crafts style by brothers Edwin and Robert Grabhorn for their prestigious Grabhorn Press, which was in operation from the early 1920s to the mid-1960s in San Francisco. The frontispiece is a color woodblock print by Valenti Angelo, an Italian-born American printmaker and illustrator. Grabbhorn Press was succeeded by Arion Press, a contemporary leading publisher of limited-edition fine press books. Swarthmore has a number of Grabhorn Press and Arion Press works in the collection.
fields.Author: Grabhorn Press, frontispiece by Valenti Angelo

fields.Work: Marcel Duchamp, Notes et/and Notations (3 volumes)
fields.Description: During the period in which Marcel Duchamp was struggling to affirm the dominance of mind over hand in the creative process, he habitually recorded his thoughts on any available scrap of paper .… A limited edition of 300 near perfect collotype facsimiles of the originals was printed in 1934 under Duchamp's direct supervision (and at his own expense.) The loose documents were in a box bound in green flock-paper .… When the White Box first appeared, more than thirty years after the Green Box, the relationship of the two collections of notes was not understood. It has taken time to appreciate that the distinction between them is small. All of the notes were written over the same period, and they all pertain to the same quest - to engage in an art of rigour and purpose, stripped of pretension, affectation, and commercialism, and above all devoid of vanity …. The Green Box is a selection from a great many notes - Duchamp said that its purpose is to act as an 'ideal catalogue' for the Large Glass. More than a catalogue, it is a commentary and a manual, a key, a map, and an instruction box. — Richard Hamilton and Ecke Bonk
fields.Author: Richard Hamilton, Ecke Bonk

fields.Description: The drawings and paintings ... have been taken from the moths and butterflies ... in possession of the author. They are of natural size ... and are painted as nearly like the originals as colors can make them ... This book was created by my grandfather, Henry Voorhees Lesley ... given to my father, William Wood Lesley, his son, and my mother, Lillian Clothier Lesley, his daughter-in-law as a Christmas gift – 1891. —Victoria Clothier Lesley Steigelman, Class of 1914
fields.Author: Henry Voorhees Lesley

fields.Description: This portfolio is a rare complete set of astronomical drawings created by French lithographer Étienne Trouvelot, who began drawing his astronomical observations in the late 19th century. As his work gained attention, he was invited to use the U.S. Naval Observatory’s refractor. In 1882, Scribner & Sons published a portfolio of fifteen of his works as chromolithographs, a chemical process in which a color print is created using multiple lithographic stones. Today the Trouvelot portfolio is highly valued for its artistic rather than scientific merits. The work was originally part of the Sproul Observatory Library collection.
fields.Author: Étienne Léopold Trouvelot

fields.Description: Rimbaud’s poem of 1873 is translated from the original French by Paul Schmidt and accompanied by seven photographs by Mapplethorpe in response to the poem.
fields.Author: Robert Mapplethorpe, poetry by Arthur Rimbaud

fields.Work: Bon Bon Mots: A Fine Assortment of Books
fields.Description: I got the idea for the format of _Bon Bon Mots _about two years before I actually made the book. In my mind’s eye, I could clearly see a collection of intimate, confectionlike book-objects. They would be so appealing that the reader could not resist holding each one in his or her hand and reading the contents. This, I thought, would be the perfect way to present contents that might not be so pleasant after all. Among the ‘sweets’ in the confection box are a phrasebook of social graces and a calendar recording each day’s guilt and worries. The texts mix sadness and sweetness in equal proportions. —Julie Chen
fields.Author: Julie Chen

fields.Description: This work includes a signed drypoint etching by Picasso. The book was part of a large personal collection of rare and valuable art books given to Swarthmore by William S. Lieberman, Class of 1943, whom the New York Times referred to as, “a legendary museum figure who held top curatorial posts at both the Museum of Modern Art and the Metropolitan Museum of Art, steering major collections to the institutions.”
fields.Author: Pierre André Benoit, illustrated by Pablo Picasso

fields.Description: _Non-Flowering Plants_ was created altering a book published by Golden Press. All the pages are still bound and none of the imagery has been moved. As I cut through the pages I have revealed the layers of mushrooms, ferns, molds and other illustrations to create a relief sculpture with the content of the book. —James Allen
fields.Author: James Allen

fields.Description: This copy of the musical score for _South Pacific_ is inscribed to James Michener from Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein. Michener’s Pulitzer Prize-winning short story collection _Tales of the South Pacific_ was the inspiration for the hit Broadway musical and Oscar-winning film. The score is also signed by James Michener, Class of 1929, who granted Swarthmore College the royalties and copyrights to most of his works, which continue to support the college’s endowment. The score is part of the Michener Collection, which contains most of his published editions.
fields.Author: Richard Rodgers, Oscar Hammerstein, II, Joshua Logan, James Michener

fields.Description: _Character Traits_, draws inspiration from the tradition of writing manuals and calligraphic model books, in which various lettering styles are displayed in short, epigrammatic texts. The title was chosen to evoke the two primary motivations of the book: to explore the traits of alphabetical characters that are digitally native and thus free from the technological limitations of typographic lettering (i.e. metal type), and to do so in a series of texts that are chosen because they illuminate various human character traits. —Russell Maret
fields.Author: Russell Maret

fields.Description: French artist Jean Dubuffet was influenced by what he called "art brut" or outsider art created by non-artists. He rebelled against traditional standards of beauty and fine art. This work consists of text and heliogravures, prints created from engravings.
fields.Author: Jean Dubuffet

fields.Description:
_Inception_ is inspired by stories and journeys of the immigrants and refugees. It is a bilingual codex in English and Arabic. The book is based on the twelfth-century Persian verse poem 'The Conference of the Birds' written by Farid Aldin Al-Attar. The poem is about the search for truth and integrity, which is parallel to the immigrants and refugee's quest to re-discover themselves. —Islam Aly

_Inception_ was made as part of Swarthmore College's Friends, Peace, and Sanctuary project. Major support for Friends, Peace, and Sanctuary was provided by The Pew Center for Arts & Heritage with additional support from Swarthmore College Libraries, the Lang Center for Civic and Social Responsibility, the William J. Cooper Foundation, and the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.
fields.Author: Islam Aly

fields.Description: In _Transforming Hate: An Artist’s Book_, I was trying to look at what it was like for me to turn the hateful words of the white supremacist books into a beautiful art object. That exploration helped me understand more fully the many levels of oppression and violence at the intersections of race, gender, class and sexual orientation. Why do we keep each other from being who we really are? How can we begin to talk about what separates us? —Clarissa Sligh
fields.Author: Clarissa Sligh

fields.Description: Sol LeWitt was a leader of the Conceptual Art movement, in which the idea for a work was stressed more than the finished formal work. This book is focused around sequences of lines and marks, rather than being dependent on the structure of the book to create the work. Like Ed Ruscha, LeWitt created works in inexpensively made multiples, allowing for a wide distribution, thus making his work more accessible to a larger audience than would be allowed with a more traditional and expensive artist’s book format. This work retains thepost-it notes that were originally affixed to it.
fields.Author: Sol LeWitt

fields.Description: _Prism_ described itself as "a summer journal of letters ... a magazine whose primary aim would be the publication of good writing ... a magazine as many-sided as the prism." Contributors included Paul Trachtman, Class of 1959, and Maurice Eldridge, Class of 1961.
fields.Author: Maurice G. Eldridge, Paul Trachtman

fields.Work: We Hunger, We Suffer & We Thirsty
fields.Description: CUBA, also known as Clarence Robbs, is a graffiti artist in the Bay Area. He was involved in the creation of the 'Wild style' graffiti movement that became prominent in the 1980s and 1990s. He develops fonts from his graffiti that he then uses to explore urban themes.
fields.Author: CUBA

fields.Work: A History of British Quadrupeds, including the Cetacea
fields.Description: This book about mammals is most noteworthy due to its having a single fore-edge painting on one side of the book page edges. The painting is invisible when the book is closed but is seen when the pages are fanned. The painting is a view of Newcastle on Tyne, England. The fore-edge technique became popular in the 18th century. This book was donated to Swarthmore by Mary Palmer Lichtenberg, Class of 1931.
fields.Author: Thomas Bell

fields.Description: Roycroft, a reformist community of about 500 craft workers and artists at its peak, was part of the Arts & Crafts Movement in the United States. Elbert Hubbard (1856–1915), who had traveled to England and been heavily influenced by the ideas and design aesthetic of William Morris and the Kelmscott Press, founded the community in 1895 in the village of East Aurora, New York. Participants were known as Roycrofters, and the Roycroft Press began printing books in 1896. Hubbard and his wife, noted suffragist Alice Moore Hubbard, died in the sinking of the RMS Lusitania in 1915, and thereafter the community began to decline. Swarthmore has a number of Roycroft books in the collection.
fields.Author: Elbert Hubbard

fields.Description: Marion "Marni" DeKay Rous Hodgkin, Class of 1939, wrote this mystery set on Swarthmore’s campus. Victims are pushed over the train trestle, pushed out of the Clothier tower, and fall over the railing from the third floor in Parrish. The book opens in the stacks of the old pre-McCabe library where the stacks were anchored on the cement basement floor, but the floors didn't actually touch the stacks themselves higher up, i.e. there was a space between the floor and the stack, where books could fall through, notes could be pushed down through, and feet could be be seen moving through the opaque glass floor above.
fields.Author: M. R. Hodgkin

fields.Description: This first American imprint of the seminal work by Audubon contains 435 illustrations of North American birds made with hand-colored plates**.** The seven-volume set was donated to Swarthmore by Jean Powell Craig, Class of 1952.
fields.Author: John James Audubon

fields.Description: _Black at Swarthmore_ is a viewbook aimed at recruiting black high school students, created by Swarthmore Afro-American Student Society (SASS) member Don Mizell, Class of 1971, and printed by the Swarthmore College Bulletin in 1969, 1970 and 1973.
fields.Author: Don Mizell, conceived of by the Swarthmore Afro-American Student Society

fields.Work: Pollucis Uocabularii index in Latinum tralatus: ut uel Graece nescientibus nota sint
fields.Description: This Greek dictionary from the Aldine Press provides information on a variety of subjects, including mythology, customs, nature, and poetry. The Aldine Press was founded by in 1495 by Aldus Manutius (1459/1452-1515), an Italian humanist and printer. After his death the press was taken over by his son and then grandson, printing books until 1597. Swarthmore owns three “Aldines.” The bookplate has the printed name of Frederick Iliff, along with a handwritten notation "G.C. Verplanck, 1856." There is a handwritten note on the front endpaper and handwritten notations in the margins throughout. Clayton Richard Perry, Class of 1973, gave the book to Swarthmore after it had been in his family for many years.
fields.Author: Julius Pollux

fields.Description: Published in 1991 to raise money for the AIDS Crisis Trust, this collaboration between artist David Hockney and poet Stephen Spender invited writers to respond to letters of the alphabet drawn by Hockney. The writers who responded included Douglas Adams, Martin Amis, Julian Barnes, William Boyd, Anthony Burgess, Margaret Drabble, T.S. Eliot, Patrick Leigh Fermor, William Golding, Seamus Heaney, Ted Hughes, Kazuo Ishiguro, Erica Jong, Doris Lessing, Norman Mailer, Ian McEwan, Arthur Miller, Iris Murdoch, Nigel Nicolson, John Julius Norwich, Joyce Carol Oates, V.S. Pritchett, Craig Raine, Susan Sontag, Paul Theroux, John Updike, and Gore Vidal. The only writer to decline was Norman Mailer, and his polite reject letter was published as his contribution.
fields.Author: David Hockney, Stephen Spender

fields.Work: Abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz; Also Known as the Alphabet Poem
fields.Description: Emmett Williams was an American poet and artist who was part of the Fluxus and concrete poetry movements. This copy of his  alphabet poem was printed on a long scroll. The work was first published ca. 1961.
fields.Author: Emmett Williams

fields.Description: The David H. Keller Collection, donated to Swarthmore in the 1980s, consists of science fiction and fantasy pulp magazines from the 1920s through the 1960s. Dr. Keller (1880-1965) was a Philadelphia-area psychiatrist who achieved renown as a fiction writer during the heyday of the pulps. In addition to the approximately 160 issues of science fiction and fantasy pulp magazines at its core, the Keller Collection also features manuscripts and typescripts, correspondence (including over 120 letters exchanged by Keller and August Derleth between 1947 and 1949), and an extensive collection of fanzines from the 1930s through the 1960s.

This work, consisting of 138 index cards, is a catalogue for _955,000_, an exhibition of conceptual art that was on display from January 13 to February 8, 1970 at the Vancouver Art Gallery. Each artist in the exhibition was asked to create one or two cards to represent their work. The cards were then placed in an envelope, in no arranged order, and sold as a catalogue for $3.
fields.Author: Lucy Lippard

fields.Description: This work by Carolee Campbell is often cited as one of the most beautiful contemporary artists’ books. It is based on a group of poems, 'The Persephones,' by Nathaniel Tarn. This work consists of 12 unbound folios painted on the front and back by Campbell, with the poems printed on or next to the artwork.
fields.Author: Carolee Campbell, poetry by Nathanial Tarn

fields.Description: Mary Vaux Walcott was from a Quaker family in Philadelphia that spent time each year in the Canadian Rockies. Her success in painting flowers led to her lifelong focus on botanical illustration. After she married Charles Doolittle Walcott, secretary of the Smithsonian Institution, they spent months each summer in the Rockies. This five-volume work contains a selection of her illustrations, and was published by the Smithsonian Institution.
fields.Author: Mary Vaux Walcott

fields.Work: Novo teatro di machine et edificii per uarie et sicure operationi
fields.Description: This mechanical engineering guide contains engravings made from copper plates of mills, dams, water wheels, and the workings of various other machines. The work is part of the library’s Bathe Collection, comprising some 1,500 volumes on the history of technology before and after the Industrial Revolution. It was amassed by and then willed to Swarthmore by Greville Bathe, an author of several books on the history of technology.
fields.Author: Vittorio Zonca

fields.Description: This collection of short stories by Rudyard Kipling was custom bound in gold tooled blue morocco with red inlays by Philadelphia Quaker Elizabeth Griscom Marot (1863–1950), who worked in the bindery of the notable Doves Press, associated with the British Arts and Crafts Movement. A member of Swarthmore Monthly Meeting, she gifted her copy to Swarthmore in 1948.
fields.Author: Rudyard Kipling

fields.Description: This is visual artist Jenny Holzer's first artist's book. She copied diagrams that relate to concepts like time and space from a variety of sources, including physics textbooks. This is an unusual copy of the work as the title is missing from the front cover.
fields.Author: Jenny Holzer

fields.Description: Ashendene Press was a small yet highly regarded private British press founded by Charles St. John Hornby (1867-1946) that printed small runs of works. Influenced by the Kelmscott Press, Hornby espoused the values of the Arts and Crafts Movement. With an emphasis on quality, the press emulated the high book standards of the past, particularly incunabula, books printed in Europe during the first 50 years of printing. Ashendene was known for the use of the typeface Subiaco, designed by Emery Walker and Sidney Cockerell from a 15th-century Italian typeface. The Ashendene books have decorative bindings, unlike books printed by the Kelmscott Press.
fields.Author: Charles St. John Hornby

fields.Work: Incipiunt sermones de festis sancto[rum], et primo de sancto Andrea sermo primus
fields.Description: The importance of this book of Latin sermons printed in Germany lies in its being an incunable. Incunabula are works printed in Europe during the first 50 years of printing, generally considered to be 1450-1500.
fields.Author: Albertus Magnus

fields.Description: This Edwidge Danticat poem is about the fatal fall of an immigrant construction worker into concrete he had just poured. The poem is illustrated with two wood engravings by renowned book artist Gaylord Schanilec.
fields.Author: Edwidge Danticat, illustrated by Gaylord Schanilec

fields.Description: Dieter Roth, a Swiss artist known for working in a wide diversity of media and creating works made from found materials, edited this collection of concrete poetry. Concrete poetry is verse in which the arrangement or shape of the words creates the meaning, having more importance than the actual meaning of the words used.
fields.Author: Dieter Roth

fields.Description: Known as the Doves Bible, this work was printed by the Doves Press in the Arts and Crafts tradition. It is famous for the clear typeface the press designed and used in all its publications, the lack of decoration except for capitals, and the title page. After a falling out with partner Emery Walker, press founder T. J. Cobden-Sanderson “bequeathed” the typeface to the Thames, tossing it off a bridge over a nine-month period starting in 1916 so that no one could use it. This book was donated to Swarthmore by Elizabeth Griscom Marot, a bookbinder from Philadelphia who worked in the Doves Press bindery.
fields.Author: Doves Press

fields.Description: _Manayunk Bridge_ is an exploration of a bridge in Philadelphia officially known as the Pencoyd Viaduct. Built in 1918 as a railroad bridge, it was taken out of use in 1986. It has since been converted into a pedestrian bridge, connecting the Cynwyd Heritage Trail in Lower Merion on the west side of the Schuylkill River to Philadelphia’s Manayunk neighborhood on the east side.
fields.Author: Thomas Parker Williams, photography by Mary Agnes Williams

fields.Description: The Eragny Press was a private press founded by Lucien Pissarro, son of the French impressionist painter Camille Pissarro. Named after the French village where the Pissarro family lived, the press was associated with the British Arts and Crafts Movement. Inspired by both the Kelmscott Press and French impressionist painting, Eragny printed 32 titles, of which there are 16 in Swarthmore’s collection.
fields.Author: Lucien Pissarro

fields.Description: _Twentysix Gasoline Stations _is the best known of Ruscha's artists' books, taken of gas stations along the route from his home in Los Angeles to his parents' home in Oklahoma City. Associated with the Pop Art movement, Ruscha had a huge impact on the development of artists’ books. He is considered by some to be the first true book artist. He published his books in multiples—highly visible, accessible, and inexpensive. His works established a new paradigm for artists’ books, turning away from the traditional livre d’artiste’s ideal of craftsmanship, luxury, and exclusivity.
fields.Author: Edward Ruscha

fields.Description: The poet W. H. Auden taught at Swarthmore from 1942 through 1945. This book contains marginalia written in Auden’s handwriting, including one page where he wrote, “Oh God, what rubbish” next to his work. Alongside the book are sign-out call slips Auden filled out when he took books out of the library, along with a few signed pink slips, which faculty filled out so that annual overdue notices could be written and sent out.
fields.Author: W. H. Auden

fields.Description: Bella Chagall, wife and muse of artist Marc Chagall, wrote two volumes of her memoirs, which Marc Chagall published after her death. Written in Yiddish, these works contain ink drawings by Marc Chagall. _Di Ershte Bagegenish_ (First Encounter) is the second volume. Swarthmore's copy was donated by Byron and Nan Waksman, Class of 1940, and Selman Waksman, Class of 1972.
fields.Author: Bella Chagall, illustrated by Marc Chagall

fields.Description: This illustrated alphabet by American visual artist Man Ray contains handwritten words and black-and-white images for each letter, some letters having more than one word. It is inscribed by Man Ray on the front flyleaf.
fields.Author: Man Ray

fields.Description:
In 1999, Xu Bing accepted an invitation to lecture at Duke University in Durham, North Carolina, and serve as artist-in-residence ... Xu Bing was intrigued by the ironical paradox that this tobacco capital continued to promote tobacco products but at the same time established an advanced medical center for cancer treatment … Through trips to farms, factories, and historical sites, coupled with archival research and reading, Xu came to understand the deep intertwined bond between the people, the industry, the Duke family, the university, and the city. —Xu Bing

The work contains ‘Zhonghua’ brand cigarettes, rubber-stamped with various English texts from _Quotations by Chairman Mao (Little Red Book)_ in original metal cases.
fields.Author: Xu Bing

fields.Work: Ici Commence la Danse Macabre des Femmes Suivi de la Danse Nouvelle des Hommes
fields.Description: _The Dance of Death _is a medieval allegory teaching that no one can escape death. This reproduction of a 1491 incunable, a work printed during the first 50 years of printing, contains a modern French translation of the 1491 texts with lithographs by Greek artist Velestinlēs Rēgas (1757?-1798).
fields.Author: Anne-Marie Yvon, Jacques Yvon, illustrated by Velestinlēs Rēgas

fields.Work: The Prose Romances of Edgar A. Poe: Containing The Murders in the Rue Morgue, and The Man that Was Used Up
fields.Description: This is a very rare first publication of Poe’s _Murders in the Rue Morgue_, the only issue of this serial ever published. Only fourteen known copies of this work survive. According to Elmore Mundell, who wrote _Poe’s 1843 Murders in the Rue Morgue: A Census of Known Copies, _the provenance of Swarthmore’s copy is as follows: “‘found in a volume of pamphlets by Edward Eberstat [[Eberstadt]] & Sons, New York booksellers, about 1940.’ Based on this statement, this copy is presumably the one noted by Heartman & Canny as belonging to Edward Eberstadt of New York City (p. 79). The book was purchased by Donald S. Stralem, prior to 1962. It was purchased by William E. Stockhausen prior to August 20, 1969, apparently through the Seven Gables Bookshop, in New York. Purchased by Michael M. Rea, probably from the 1974 sale. Rea, who died in 1996, donated part of his library, including the Poe book, to Swarthmore College.”
fields.Author: Edgar Allan Poe

fields.Description: This Bible is the only illuminated manuscript in the collection and is believed to have been completed in Northern France in the 13th century. The manuscript is vellum, with some gold leaf, and has colored red and blue initials. It is missing the title page and some leaves at the end. It was purchased at auction by Swarthmore in 1984 and rebound in 1985.
fields.Author: Copyist unknown

fields.Description: These letters from William Wordsworth are part of the Wells Collection, compiled by John Edwin Wells, Class of 1896, a James Thomson scholar. The collection was bequeathed to Swarthmore in 1943 and is composed of two small, fairly complete sets of 18th- and 19th-century editions of James Thomson and William Wordsworth. Also included are critical works, biographies, transcripts and photostats of letters, musical settings of poems, books about the Lake District, maps, postcards, guides, and concordances, as well as books, some annotated, from Wordsworth's own personal library.
fields.Author: William Wordsworth

fields.Work: Travels Through the Interior Parts of America
fields.Description: Thomas Anburey was a British explorer who wrote of his travels in North America in the 1770s-1780s. He fought under General John Burgoyne in the Battle of Saratoga in 1777. Taken prisoner, he eventually returned to Britain in 1781. This work is part of the British Americana Collection, founded in 1939 in response to the college's close association in the 1930s with the Rhodes Trust. It contains travel accounts by British visitors to the United States. The accounts include novels, biographies, memoirs, and bibliographies of travel dating back to the 1580s. Readers can find highly vituperative to equally gracious descriptions of the United States, and occasionally, Swarthmore itself.
fields.Author: Thomas Anburey

fields.Description: Letters are blind stamped on a continuous strip, folded in half lengthwise to form a double strip, then folded accordion style and attached at its ends to inlaid-wood boards. Letters A to M read from front to back; letters from N to Z read from back to front. —Ronald King
fields.Author: Ronald King

fields.Description: This Dickens first edition_ _was issued in 20 parts as 19 monthly installments with one double issue, which was the manner in which his books were originally published. Each part was encased in a green printed wrapper and then housed inside a slipcase that resembles a book.
fields.Author: Charles Dickens

fields.Description: _The Dance of Death _by German artist Hans Holbein (1497–1543) is a well known series of Renaissance woodblock prints of the medieval allegory in which Death summons people from all levels of society to dance their way to their grave, showing that in death everyone is united. This edition was printed by Arthur K. Sabin at the Temple Sheen Press in 1916.
fields.Author: Hans Holbein, enlarged facsimiles of the original wood engravings by Hans Lützelberger

fields.Work: News from Nowhere: Or, an Epoch of Rest, Being some Chapters from a Utopian Romance
fields.Description: This book is a classic example of the Kelmscott Press, founded by William Morris, a designer and writer associated with the British Arts and Crafts Movement. His books were inspired by the book standards of the past, especially incunabula, books printed in Europe during the first 50 years of printing. Kelmscott books were made from the highest quality materials, beautiful and well crafted. Morris had a holistic approach to book design, designing his own typefaces, making his own paper, and printing everything by hand. The title page of _News from Nowhere_ is representative of the iconic decorative title pages created by the press.
fields.Author: William Morris

fields.Work: Les Malheurs des Immortels Révélés par Paul Eluard et Max Ernst
fields.Description: A hors commerce copy printed on rose paper of the second edition of this early Surrealist work first printed in 1922. The work includes poems by Paul Eluard with matching collages by Max Ernst.
fields.Author: Paul Eluard, Max Ernst

fields.Description: This miniature book, written in Latin, has a single fore-edge painting on one side of the book page edges. The painting is invisible when the book is closed but is seen when the pages are fanned. The painting is a water scene with ships and cliffs in the background. The technique became popular in the 18th century. There is an inscription on front fly-leaf: "Received from his grace the Most Revd. Dr. Carew Archbishop of S. Western Bengal, 19th Feb. 1854."
fields.Author: Claude Arvisenet

fields.Description: This two-volume work of the tragedies of Sophocles, written in Greek with Latin translations, was owned by Thomas Jefferson. It was auctioned off in 1829, three years after his death, to pay off debts owed on the Monticello estate. Scholars are able to identify works owned by Jefferson through his placement of his initials in the margins. There is a list believed to be in Jefferson’s handwriting on the inside of the front cover of Vol. 1.  This copy of the work appears to have been purchased by G. C. Verplanck (1786–1870) from the Jefferson estate. Verplanck was a New York senator, attorney, and writer. Clayton Richard Perry, Class of 1973, gave the books to Swarthmore after they had been in his family for many years.
fields.Author: Sophocles

fields.Description: Nauman created this work of photographs of the polluted skies of Los Angeles to contrast with his earlier work of clean blue skies in _Clear Sky. _This work was part of Multiples Inc.'s _Artists and Photographs_ box of 1970.
fields.Author: Bruce Nauman

fields.Description: Born in Suriname, Stanley Brouwn moved to the Netherlands in the 1950s, where he became part of the Fluxus and Conceptual Art movements. Notably inaccessible, he did not give interviews or allow photographs to be taken of him. His work focused on measurements, motion, and distances. This work consists of xerox pages of a computer printout.
fields.Author: Stanley Brouwn

fields.Work: Sir Thomas'more, or Utopia Impaled: A Memento Mori
fields.Description: I realized that the American junk food snack S’mores could be an appropriate guise for Sir Thomas More in numerous ways  … More also punned on his name as morus, which is both fool and mulberry in Latin, and planted a mulberry tree in his garden in Chelsea. Accordingly, the white pages inside the graham cracker volume are composed of mulberry paper. The title also contains the Latin word for death: ‘mors’. A memento mori is a token or memento of someone’s death. Sir Thomas More invented the pun ‘Memento Mori aeris’ (remember More’s money) as Memento morieris (the remembrance of death). More meditated on death his whole life, and chose destruction by the juggernaut Henry VIII in order to uphold his own faith to the supremacy of the Catholic Pope. —Angela Lorenz
fields.Author: Angela Lorenz

fields.Description: This fully hand-embroidered fabric book replicates a traditional composition notebook, with an orange and white marbled cover. The text focuses on coincidences.
fields.Author: Candace Hicks

fields.Description: _Dream Days_, first published in 1898, is the sequel to Kenneth Grahame's _The Golden Age. _This American edition contains photogravures of illustrations by Maxfield Parrish, who was from Philadelphia and attended Haverford College. The enormous success of the work contributed greatly to Parrish's fame. This copy was given to Swarthmore by Julien Cornell, Class of 1930.
fields.Author: Kenneth Grahame, illustrated by Maxfield Parrish
